University of Maryland SP2 Lab

Security. Privacy. People.


In SP2, we research how security and privacy affect people, and how people affect security and privacy. We use methods and tools from computer science and social science to investigate how and why people make security- and privacy-relevant decisions, and to give people tools to make better decisions.
We are affiliated with the Maryland Cybersecurity Center and the Human-Computer Interaction Lab.

All Selected Publications

All Selected Publications

Here is a collection of our selected publications spanning security behaviors, privacy concerns, user attitudes, and secure development practices, with insights into both technical and human-centered approaches to security and privacy.

All Publications

Learning and Adopting Security Behaviors

Exploring where and how people learn security behavior and decide which to adopt, and investigating how to improve security advice and communications.

Selected Publications

Human Aspects of Secure Software Development

Understanding how and why developers introduce security problems.

Selected Publications

For More Information

Or to join our participant panel, visit the Security Professionals page.

Security and Privacy for At-Risk Users

Exploring the security and privacy needs of at-risk, vulnerable, and marginalized users.

Selected Publications

Security Professionals

Exploring how security professionals do their work, measuring best practices, and developing better tools and processes.

Selected Publications

For More Information

Or to join our participant panel, visit the Security Professionals page.

Adoption and Understanding of Secure Communications

Exploring mental models of secure communication and developing strategies to promote their adoption and effective use.

Selected Publications

Transparency in Online Tracking and Inferencing

Making tracking and inferencing more visible; exploring user reactions and preferences.

Selected Publications

Research Methods in Human-Centered Security

Comparing and characterizing methods for sampling and data collection, documenting best practices, and building research tools.

Selected Publications

Other fun projects

Assorted whatchamacallits and thingamajigs.
